image.altText: A man stands on a balcony with a frown on his face.

items.synopsis: Insurance companies have responded to back-to-back floods and soaring building costs by hiking premiums by around 30 per cent in just one year. But for the riskiest homes, cover is either refused outright, or offered at prices few can afford.

title.children: 'Who can afford that?' Scott was quoted nearly $32K for home and contents insurance as premiums soar

image.altText: An AFL player in a black training shirt, catches a football

items.synopsis: Maynard's season will be over if Collingwood is unable to throw out the defender's ban for rough conduct. Follow live.

title.children: 'Inherently dangerous': AFL counsel takes aim as Pies' star Brayden Maynard fights for his season at tribunal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ihle says that the footage shows that Maynard has his eyes on the ball virtually the whole time. He adds that it's a fair assessment that the amount that Maynard jumped forward was basically one or two metres, "a stride length". "The AFL says that this decision to jump in these circumstances - and the circumstances as Mr Maynard saw them - was careless for him to jump in this way," Ihle says. Ihle says his submission is that there is nothing inherently dangerous in the decision to jump, adding that Maynard was entitled to come off his player off centre half back and come forward, and that "he was entitled to jump when Brayshaw was about to kick". Ihle takes the footage through from another angle, saying "the Tribunal can clearly see that he (Maynard) has largely jumped straight up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nothing inherently dangerous in decision to jump, Maynard's counsel says

children.content: Ihle says that the footage shows that Maynard has his eyes on the ball virtually the whole time. He adds that it's a fair assessment that the amount that Maynard jumped forward was basically one or two metres, "a stride length".
"The AFL says that this decision to jump in these circumstances - and the circumstances as Mr Maynard saw them - was careless for him to jump in this way," Ihle says.

Ihle says his submission is that there is nothing inherently dangerous in the decision to jump, adding that Maynard was entitled to come off his player off centre half back and come forward, and that "he was entitled to jump when Brayshaw was about to kick".
Ihle takes the footage through from another angle, saying "the Tribunal can clearly see that he (Maynard) has largely jumped straight up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ben Ihle says this is a question of what is reasonable or unreasonable. It's not an automatic offence simply because of the contact. Ihle says that there are two elements of conduct that Maynard is being looked at for. Electing to try and smother in the way he did (while airborne), and any bump while falling from his peak trajectory. "Trying as he might nobly on behalf of the AFL, Mr Woods can't point to what he did do..." relating to the second area of conduct. Chair Gleeson cuts in, saying that the argument is what Maynard didn't do, rather than what he did. "When one considers the guidelines... only applies where there has been a decision to bump - it would only apply to the falling portion," he says. "We believe one of two things (from the prosecution). Either we are satisfied Maynard had time to make a conscious decision to bump and bumped, or as Professor Cole says, he made a predetermined decision to bump before he even left the ground. "It was never put to Mr Maynard that he made a decision to bump, or that he made a decision and had time as he was falling from his peak trajectory." Ihle says this is not a case of a decision to bump at all.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maynard's counsel Ben Ihle makes submissions

children.content: Ben Ihle says this is a question of what is reasonable or unreasonable. It's not an automatic offence simply because of the contact.

Ihle says that there are two elements of conduct that Maynard is being looked at for. Electing to try and smother in the way he did (while airborne), and any bump while falling from his peak trajectory.
"Trying as he might nobly on behalf of the AFL, Mr Woods can't point to what he did do..." relating to the second area of conduct.
Chair Gleeson cuts in, saying that the argument is what Maynard didn't do, rather than what he did.
"When one considers the guidelines... only applies where there has been a decision to bump - it would only apply to the falling portion," he says.

"We believe one of two things (from the prosecution). Either we are satisfied Maynard had time to make a conscious decision to bump and bumped, or as Professor Cole says, he made a predetermined decision to bump before he even left the ground.
"It was never put to Mr Maynard that he made a decision to bump, or that he made a decision and had time as he was falling from his peak trajectory."
Ihle says this is not a case of a decision to bump at all.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chair Gleeson is questioning Professor Cole. Asked whether there was any chance of changing his position once airborne, he says that based on the numbers and research, it's difficult to conclusively say Maynard would have been able to make a conscious decision. A minute later, he uses a memorable line to describe human momentum in mid-air. "Once he's in flight he's basically a projectile ... a frisbee with legs".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Once he's in flight, he's basically a projectile': Professor Cole talks about the mechanics

children.content: Chair Gleeson is questioning Professor Cole.

Asked whether there was any chance of changing his position once airborne, he says that based on the numbers and research, it's difficult to conclusively say Maynard would have been able to make a conscious decision.
A minute later, he uses a memorable line to describe human momentum in mid-air.
"Once he's in flight he's basically a projectile ... a frisbee with legs".

image.altText: A woman in a formal red dress stands in front of a lectern, with blue curtains behind her.

items.synopsis: Australia's new sex discrimination commissioner says she's appalled to hear former Coalition cabinet minister, Karen Andrews's accusations of harassment.

title.children: 'Appals me': Sex discrimination commissioner appalled to hear of Karen Andrews harassment allegations

image.altText: An elderly woman holds up a small poster that reads 'vote no', as part of a rally for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

items.synopsis: The No campaign has been accused of asking volunteers to spread "fear and misinformation" in an effort to convince referendum voters of its agenda.

title.children: Voice No campaign accused of asking volunteers to 'flat out lie'

image.altText: An adult emu and four chicks cross a road in an outback town.

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old was issued a $619 infringement notice for driving without due care and attention following the incident in Longreach.

title.children: Woman fined over emu chick deaths in outback town following road incident

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: After months of negotiations, the government’s signature housing promise is set to pass the Senate. So how many new homes will be built, how soon, and where across the country?

title.children: Where will these new homes be built? Here's what the government's new housing bill means for you

image.altText: A close up shot of police tape with cars parked on a street and trees blurred in the background

items.synopsis: Detectives appeal for information after a man allegedly approached a 12-year-old girl in Warnbro on Monday and grabbed her shirt before she managed to escape.

title.children: Police investigating reports of second alleged attempted child abduction in Perth's southern suburbs

image.altText: A pharmacist standing behind a counter holding a prescription basket towards the camera

items.synopsis: Parents and carers are warned that a shortage affecting the most-prescribed antibiotics for children is set to continue until early next year.

title.children: The most-prescribed antibiotics for children are in critically short supply across the country

image.altText: A mother and father with a child in a wheelchair, and another child on a swing.

items.synopsis: Barely two months ago, Spencer Barton was an active and energetic five-year-old — but a shock diagnosis has turned the lives of him and his parents upside down, and left them battling not only his condition but the health system.

title.children: 5yo's 'truly heartbreaking' health battle leaves his family struggling to secure support

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un waves from a private train.

items.synopsis: Kim Jong Un's trip to Russia by rail has drawn attention to the traditional method of travel for North Korean leaders — luxury, armoured trains that have long been a part of the dynasty's lore.

title.children: Kim Jong Un has arrived in Russia by rail. Here's a look at his luxury armoured train

image.altText: A young man wearing a grey hoodie.

items.synopsis: A boy who repeatedly stabbed "typical, cheeky teenager" Declan Cutler during a deadly gang attack on a Melbourne street is jailed for 15 years.

title.children: Teens jailed over 'savage and totally unprovoked' fatal attack on Melbourne 16yo

image.altText: Burnt-out cars

items.synopsis: Firefighters confirm sparks spread from a detached lithium-ion battery from a luxury electric car to four nearby vehicles parked at Sydney Airport last night.

title.children: Five cars destroyed at Sydney Airport after EV battery explosion

image.altText: A pregnant woman in a white dress with a horse on a beach.

items.synopsis: Emma Goyne believes she picked up the parasitic infection while cleaning her horse stable, which a neighbouring cat had been using as a litter box. Now she's pushing for tougher cat laws.

title.children: 'Cat poo on my hands': Emma fell sick when pregnant. She wants cat laws tightened

image.altText: Doody Shucking

items.synopsis: A south coast oyster farmer who can shuck 30 in under three minutes hopes that's quick enough to beat the world's best.

title.children: Gerard Dennis grew up 600km from the coast, now he hopes to be crowned the best oyster shucker in the world

image.altText: An aerial view shows the charred remains of a building, with sparse trees nearby

items.synopsis: With a seemingly endless supply of guns, money and young men willing to act as mercenaries, tribal fighting in PNG has become akin to guerilla warfare.

title.children: Violence is so bad in this PNG community that police sealed it off to outsiders. The ABC got to go inside

image.altText: Two kids hug a family member - anonymous.

items.synopsis: New research from Anglicare Australia finds low income households are facing higher living costs, which prevents them from getting ahead financially and pushes them further into poverty.

title.children: Low income Australians are paying a 'poverty premium' for basic services, Anglicare says

image.altText: The sun sets over Kakadu National Park.

items.synopsis: The Gundjeihmi Aboriginal Corporation says a "great burden has been removed" after ORIC confirmed the end of its long-running investigation, with no findings made and no actions to be taken.

title.children: Years-long investigation dropped into Aboriginal corporation representing Kakadu TOs

image.altText: A woman with a ponytail and dark long sleeve top standing in front of a tree

items.synopsis: An expert says there's been a spike in pneumonia infections in people with healthy immune systems. Circus performer Caitlyn Larsson, who had the infection for three months this year, is one of them.

title.children: Why are even healthy people getting sick with pneumonia this year?

image.altText: A middle-aged, bespectacled man in a suit exits a court building.

items.synopsis: Maurice Molan will be fined $2,500 after pleading guilty to misconduct in public office over the 2013 engagement of an allegedly fraudulent third-party training company.

title.children: Former executive avoids conviction over $1.8m TAFE scandal

image.altText: A man wearing a car backwards stands by a bright green car, with its doors open.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for the 32-year-old accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla say police are taking too long to hand over the full brief of evidence and the case should be abandoned.

title.children: Canberra man accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla wants case against him to be dropped

image.altText: A court build with a columned verandah and a blue coloured building behind

items.synopsis: An Adelaide man accused of importing and producing child-like dolls at his Elizabeth Downs family home has been denied bail.

title.children: Man intercepted by Australian Federal Police allegedly importing child-like dolls denied bail

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears glasses and stands speaking at a podium in a room, in front of a chalkboard and computer screens

items.synopsis: Banned from Australia over an alleged foreign interference plot in New South Wales, Chen Hong maintains he has done nothing wrong and continues to criticise the diplomatic stance taken by the former Coalition government.

title.children: Chinese scholar barred from Australia takes part in high-level dialogue between nations in Beijing

image.altText: Soldiers attempt to tow a vehicle stuck in mud

items.synopsis: Harsh winter conditions will bring new challenges in the war in Ukraine. The fighting will not stop, but it will change its tempo — and both sides will face different tests, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Napoleon and Hitler battled the Marshall Mud. Could it be Putin's undoing?

image.altText: Curtin Uni Wesley players stand arm in arm in a huddle during an Aussie rules match.

items.synopsis: Amateur female players call out derogatory and sexist online commentary after the Perth Football League A-grade grand final, saying "older men" are to blame for "disgusting" behaviour.

title.children: In shocking weather, an amateur women's footy team lost a low-scoring grand final — only to cop a sexist backlash

image.altText: Woman smiling leaning on fence

items.synopsis: A renter says her life was saved by a concerned property agent after mould began to engulf the walls of her former home.

title.children: Mould in Prudence's rental home could have killed her, but help came from a surprising place

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: Two tourism companies on trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island volcano eruption have had charges dismissed.

title.children: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed, just one defendant remains

image.altText: Karen Andrews holds her hands up while sitting under a patio in her Queensland home

items.synopsis: Former Coalition cabinet minister Karen Andrews has revealed she endured harassment inside the House of Representatives, with a male colleague breathing heavily on the back of her neck.

title.children: The harassment Karen Andrews endured inside parliament

items.synopsis: One of them grew up in a Samoan village and didn't play a game of footy until he was 17. The other is a former reserve grade journeyman. Together, they're keeping the Roosters alive in 2023.

title.children: The unsung heroes keeping the Sydney Roosters improbable finals run alive

image.altText: A teenager boy with a surfboard on a beach under an ocean pier

items.synopsis: Gold Coast teenager Kai Colless seals the world title in his division, winning the final of the US Adaptive Surfing Championships in California just eight months after leaving hospital.

title.children: Teen wins surfing world title one year after 'scary' diagnosis limits the use of his legs
